head.title: Offshore Wind Plan: A Long Time Coming

hedline.hl1: Offshore Wind Plan: A Long Time Coming

abstract.p: Renewable Energy Long Island executive director Gordian Raacke letter on David Bishop and William Lauder's March 12 Op-Ed article about proposed wind park in waters off Long Island

block.p: In ''Turbines With a View'' (Op-Ed, March 12), about the proposed offshore wind park, David Bishop and William Lauder asserted that the project ''is based more on the whims of its corporate sponsor than on any regional energy plan or careful consideration of community concerns.''

In ''Turbines With a View'' (Op-Ed, March 12), about the proposed offshore wind park, David Bishop and William Lauder asserted that the project ''is based more on the whims of its corporate sponsor than on any regional energy plan or careful consideration of community concerns.''

Not so. In 1999, the Citizens Advisory Panel issued a report recommending a study of Long Island's offshore wind potential. In 2002, 30 grass-roots groups called for an offshore wind park in their Citizens Energy Plan.

The Long Island Power Authority and the state's Energy Research and Development Authority responded to these grass-roots voices with two feasibility studies that led to a request for proposals for the wind park, and subsequent selection of the developer. The proposal then became an integral part of LIPA's long-term energy supply plan.

The idea for an offshore wind park originated with local environmental organizations. A coalition of local, statewide and national environmental groups now supports LIPA's efforts to turn our offshore breezes into electricity that is free of pollution and fuel price increases, and does not compromise our nation's energy security.
The writer is executive director of Renewable Energy Long Island.
